channel.title: Remote shutdown
channel.description: I realize that in order to remotely shutdown a computer you can go to the CMD prompt and type shutdown -i............but how do i know what to type in for the [i]ADD COMPUTERS tab[/i]

item.title: Remote shutdown
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“magma828, post:1, topic:171686”][quote author=Hiaburi link=topic=231324.msg1983451#msg1983451 date=1199704294]
Lol actually i am glad some one posted this. I am having trouble with my home network, i have about 11 computers in my house and i own the network and all, but i do not have admin privileges on my network, like i cant view user groups or change system info from my pc, i have all the computers on the same workgroup and all but i cant even get shutdown -i to work, any help on giving myself privileges to work with this?
[/quote]
I don’t know how your router works, but there should be some setting on there that you can change which gives different users different privileges. You will probably need the admin user and pass which is admin, admin by default but probably changed.[/quote]

Lolol, messing with the router config still won’t give him remote administrative privileges on the machines he’s trying to shut down.

Sure, you’ll get through checkpoint A, but not through checkpoint B.

Read full topic

item.title: Remote shutdown
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

shutdown -i usually doesn’t work that well. If you still wanted to try, you’d add the other computer’s IP addresses into that field.

To get an IP address for a computer on the local network, go to that computer, click Start, click Run, type “cmd” with no quotes, hit enter, type “ipconfig” with no quotes, hit enter, and then look for a number that starts with 192.168., that is the internal IP of that computer.

The internal IP would be what you’d want to type into the “add computers” tab (if the computer is on your network), but just so you know, it probably won’t work because most computers don’t accept remote shutdown requests.

Read full topic
